S8.T1.table:

TripAdvisor 1,705 623,567 871,689
Yelp 60,785 366,715 1,569,264
references:
The dataset. 
We use four public datasets to evaluate the accuracy of our AC-RP method,
whose overall statistics are summarized in Table 1.
The dataset from Amazon was published in  and it
contains historical ratings of movies in Amazon.
The dataset from Google Local was published in 
and it contains reviews about businesses from Google Local (Google Maps).
The dataset from TripAdvisor was published in ,
and it contains historical ratings of hotels in TripAdvisor.
The dataset from Yelp was downloaded from the link <sup class="ltx_note_mark">2</sup>
2<sup class="ltx_note_mark">2</sup>
22https://www.yelp.com/dataset
and it contains historical ratings for restaurants in Yelp.

For fair comparison with Herd, we use the same method as HIALF (Zhang2019, ) to extract training dataset and testing dataset. Similar with HIALF , for each item in Table (Zhang2019, ) to extract training dataset and testing dataset. Similar with HIALF , for each item in Table 1, we only select items with an medium positive average rating, i.e., average rating in the range [ 3.9 , 4.1 ] 3.9 4.1 [3.9,4.1] [ 3.9 , 4.1 ] out. For each selected item we extract all its ratings and the associated users out. We then remove items with less than 50 training ratings, to avoid over-fitting. Table [ 3.9 , 4.1 ] 3.9 4.1 [3.9,4.1] [ 3.9 , 4.1 ] [ 3.9 , 4.1 ] [ [3.9 3.9, ,4.1 4.1] ] 3.9 4.1 3.9 4.1 3.9 3.94.1 4.1[3.9,4.1] [3.9,4.1][ 3.9 , 4.1 ] [ 3.9 , 4.1 ] out. For each selected item we extract all its ratings and the associated users out. We then remove items with less than 50 training ratings, to avoid over-fitting. Table 2 summarizes overall statistics of the selected data. One can observe that after this selection, some datasets still contain around two hundred thousands of users. Comparing the number of ratings with the number of users, one can observe that the rating matrix is very sparse. Similar with HIALF , we further aggregate users with twenty ratings (or fifty) as a big user for Googlelocal and TripAdvisor ( or Amazon-movie and Yelp). Furthermore, for each selected item, we use its last 25 ratings as test ratings and use all other ratings as training ratings. We train the models on the training dataset, and validate the model on the testing dataset.

references:
Parameter setting.
To prevent over fitting, we set appropriate regularization hyper parameters for our models.
Following similar principle in HIALF ,
we consider the regularization hyper parameters summarized in Table 3.
Following previous work ,
we choose the dimension of latent features as <math alttext="\kappa=5" class="ltx_Math" display="inline" id="S8.SS2.p4.1.m1.1">

Impact of arrival order. 
The are two types of weights on ratings,
i.e., based on arrival order and based on arrival time stamp of ratings.
Here we study the weight which is based on arrival order.

italic_η start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is polynomial or logarithmic in the arrival order of ratings.
This implies that one can further improve the rating prediction accuracy
via tuning the weight of ratings based on the arrival order.
This improvement on rating prediction accuracy is supported by
that users tend to assign larger weights to more recent ratings 
Furthermore, this improvement
is achieved at simple selections of the weight of ratings.
One can further improve the rating prediction accuracy by finer tuning of weights.

Impact of arrival order. 
The are two types of weights on ratings,
i.e., based on arrival order and based on arrival time stamp of ratings.
Here we study the weight which is based on arrival order.
We fix <math alttext="n=20" class="ltx_Math" display="inline" id="S8.SS3.p3.1.m1.1">

we consider three types of weights associated with the arrival order of ratings,
i.e., exponential, polynomial and logarithmic in the arrival order,
which are stated in Table

To study the impact of arrival order,
we consider three types of weights associated with the arrival order of ratings,
i.e., exponential, polynomial and logarithmic in the arrival order,
which are stated in Table 5.
Table 5 shows that RMSE of our R-BE method
under these three types of weights.

</math> is polynomial or logarithmic in the arrival order of ratings.
This implies that one can further improve the rating prediction accuracy
via tuning the weight of ratings based on the arrival order.
This improvement on rating prediction accuracy is supported by
that users tend to assign larger weights to more recent ratings 
Furthermore, this improvement
is achieved at simple selections of the weight of ratings.
One can further improve the rating prediction accuracy by finer tuning of weights.

italic_η start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is polynomial or logarithmic in the arrival order of ratings.
This implies that one can further improve the rating prediction accuracy
via tuning the weight of ratings based on the arrival order.
This improvement on rating prediction accuracy is supported by
that users tend to assign larger weights to more recent ratings 
Furthermore, this improvement
is achieved at simple selections of the weight of ratings.
One can further improve the rating prediction accuracy by finer tuning of weights.

italic_n = 20.
To study the impact of arrival time stamp,
we consider three types of weights associated with the arrival time stamp of ratings,
i.e., exponential, polynomial and logarithmic in the arrival time stamp,
which are stated in Table 6.
Table 6 shows that RMSE of our R-BE method
under these three types of weights.

This implies that one can further improve the rating prediction accuracy
via tuning the weight of ratings based on the arrival time stamp.
This improvement on rating prediction accuracy is supported by
that users tend to assign larger weights to more recent ratings

italic_η start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is polynomial or logarithmic in the arrival time stamp of ratings.
This implies that one can further improve the rating prediction accuracy
via tuning the weight of ratings based on the arrival time stamp.
This improvement on rating prediction accuracy is supported by
that users tend to assign larger weights to more recent ratings <cite class="ltx_cite ltx_citemacro_citep">(<a class="ltx_ref" href="https://arxiv.org/html/2408.10895v1#bib.bib15" title="">Rudolph2015, </a>)</cite>.
Furthermore, this improvement
is achieved at simple selections of the weight of ratings.
It can be further improved by finer tuning of weights.

This implies that one can further improve the rating prediction accuracy
via tuning the weight of ratings based on the arrival time stamp.
This improvement on rating prediction accuracy is supported by
that users tend to assign larger weights to more recent ratings <cite class="ltx_cite ltx_citemacro_citep">(<a class="ltx_ref" href="https://arxiv.org/html/2408.10895v1#bib.bib15" title="">Rudolph2015, </a>)</cite>.
Furthermore, this improvement
is achieved at simple selections of the weight of ratings.
It can be further improved by finer tuning of weights.

heterogeneity for rating prediction.
We consider the initial opinion formation model derived in
Equation (8).

This implies that one can further improve the rating prediction accuracy
via tuning the weight of rating levels, i.e., aggregate opinion heterogeneity.
This improvement on rating prediction accuracy is supported by
that users tend to assign different weights to different rating levels <cite class="ltx_cite ltx_citemacro_citep">(<a class="ltx_ref" href="https://arxiv.org/html/2408.10895v1#bib.bib15" title="">Rudolph2015, </a>)</cite>
This reduction of RMSE is achieved at simple selections on weight for rating levels.
Finer tuning of weight may lead to further reduction on the RMSE.
(Rudolph2015, )

In this section, we study the benefit of exploiting aggregate opinion
heterogeneity for rating prediction.
We consider the initial opinion formation model derived in
Equation (8).

as shown in Table 8 and 9.
This implies that one can further improve the rating prediction accuracy
via tuning the weight of rating levels, i.e., aggregate opinion heterogeneity.
This improvement on rating prediction accuracy is supported by
that users tend to assign different weights to different rating levels <cite class="ltx_cite ltx_citemacro_citep">(<a class="ltx_ref" href="https://arxiv.org/html/2408.10895v1#bib.bib15" title="">Rudolph2015, </a>)</cite>
This reduction of RMSE is achieved at simple selections on weight for rating levels.
Finer tuning of weight may lead to further reduction on the RMSE.
(Rudolph2015, )

Finer tuning of weight may lead to further reduction on the RMSE.

heterogeneity for rating prediction.

as shown in Table 8 and 9.
This implies that one can further improve the rating prediction accuracy
via tuning the weight of rating levels, i.e., aggregate opinion heterogeneity.
This improvement on rating prediction accuracy is supported by
that users tend to assign different weights to different rating levels <cite class="ltx_cite ltx_citemacro_citep">(<a class="ltx_ref" href="https://arxiv.org/html/2408.10895v1#bib.bib15" title="">Rudolph2015, </a>)</cite>
This reduction of RMSE is achieved at simple selections on weight for rating levels.
Finer tuning of weight may lead to further reduction on the RMSE.

This implies that one can further improve the rating prediction accuracy
via tuning the weight of rating levels, i.e., aggregate opinion heterogeneity.
This improvement on rating prediction accuracy is supported by
that users tend to assign different weights to different rating levels <cite class="ltx_cite ltx_citemacro_citep">(<a class="ltx_ref" href="https://arxiv.org/html/2408.10895v1#bib.bib15" title="">Rudolph2015, </a>)</cite>
This reduction of RMSE is achieved at simple selections on weight for rating levels.
Finer tuning of weight may lead to further reduction on the RMSE.
